weka.clusterers

Class LFCluster

  • java.lang.Object
    • weka.clusterers.AbstractClusterer
      • weka.clusterers.RandomizableClusterer
        • weka.clusterers.LFCluster
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, weka.clusterers.Clusterer, weka.core.CapabilitiesHandler, weka.core.OptionHandler, weka.core.Randomizable, weka.core.RevisionHandler, weka.core.TechnicalInformationHandler

    public class LFCluster
extends weka.clusterers.RandomizableClusterer
implements weka.core.TechnicalInformationHandler
    Clusterer using virtual ants to cluster Instances data on a two dimensional grid. For more information see:

    Lumer/Faieta 1994: Lumer, Erik D.; Faieta, Baldo: Diversity and Adaptation in Populations of Clustering Ants. In: Cliff, David; Husbands, Phil; Meyer, Jean-Arcady; Wilson, Stewart W. (Eds.): From Animals to Animats 3 - Proceedings of the Third International Conference on Simulation of Adaptive Behavior. Pages 501-508. Complex adaptive systems. MIT Press, Cambridge (Massachusetts), 1994.

    and for more information about the background:

    Deneubourg et al. 1991: Deneubourg, Jean Louis; Goss, Simon; Franks, Nigel R.; Sendova-Franks, Ana B.; Detrain, Claire; Chrétien, Ludovic: The Dynamics of Collective Sorting - Robot-Like Ants and Ant-Like Robots. In: Meyer, Jean-Arcady; Wilson, Stewart W. (Eds.): From Animals to Animats - Proceedings of the First International Conference on Simulation of Adaptive Behavior. Pages 356â€“365. MIT Press, Cambridge (Massachusetts), 1991.

    BibTeX: 

     @inbook{Lumer/Faieta1994,
    author = {Erik D. Lumer and Baldo Faieta},
    title = {Diversity and Adaptation in Populations of Clustering Ants},
    editor = {David Cliff, Phil Husbands, Jean-Arcady Meyer and Stewart W. Wilson},
    booktitle = {From Animals to Animats 3 - Proceedings of the Third International Conference on Simulation of Adaptive Behavior},
    series = {Complex adaptive systems},
    publisher = {MIT Press, Cambridge (Massachusetts)},
    pages = {501-508},
    year = {1994}
 }

    Valid options are: 

     -a <num>
  Alpha, coefficient for cluster similarity.
     -kp <num>
  Pick up threshold constant. The pick up threshold constant is used for
  adjusting the pick up probability.
     -kd <num>
  Drop down threshold constant. The drop down threshold constant is used for
  adjusting the drop down probability.
     -kdf <type>
  Drop down function that is used. Can use the original drop down function by
  Lumer/Faieta 1994 or the symmetric function by Deneubourg et al. 1991.
  (default = original)
     -dist <classname and options>
  Distance function that is used for instance comparison according to the
  attributes of the instances in feature space.
  (default = weka.core.EuclideanDistance (without normalization))
     -gx <num>
  Size of the 2-dimensional grid on the x axis.
     -gy <num>
  Size of the 2-dimensional grid on the y axis.
     -i <num>
  Number of ant cycles to be executed. When all ant cycles passed, the
  algorithm terminates.
     -ic <num>
  Number of ant calls per ant cycle. Each ant that is called can work and
  walk.
  (default = 10000)
     -an <num>
  Number of ants on the grid.
     -avr <num>
  Size of the neighborhood or view range of each ant. The radius defines which
  area around an ant is regarded as the ant's neighborhood.
     -as <num>
  Speed limit for all ants. The algorithm tries to find for every speed from
  1 to the defined maximum ant groups of nearly the same size and assigns them
  their individual speeds.
     -adr <num>
  Area, in which ants can drop an instance. It is measured in grid cells
  around the ant.
     -adm <num>
  Number of recent drop locations an ant can remember. When the ant remembers
  drop locations it goes to remembered locations that are most similar to the
  instance the ant is carrying.
     -abdc <num>
  After how many ant cycles carrying nothing an ant switches to destructive
  behavior. When an ant did not pick up an instance for the given amount of
  ant cycles it becomes destructive and picks up the next instance it can find
  regardless of the neighborhood of the instance.
     -abdn <num>
  When an ant picked up enough instances in destructive behavior it turns back
  to normal behavior again. This value defines how many pick ups are made in
  destructive behavior.
     -m
  Replace missing values.
     -w
  This clusterer is used to make the clusters formed by the ants clear. It is
  applied in the end, when no more ant cycles must be executed.
    Version:
    0.9
    Author:
    Christoph
    See Also:
    RandomizableClusterer, Serialized Form

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description

      Class of the ants running on the grid.

      Coordinate in an imaginary two-dimensional coordinate system.
      protected class  LFCluster.Grid
      The grid object where the LFCluster.GridInstance objects are placed and the ants run to cluster these GridInstance objects.
      protected class  LFCluster.GridInstance
      Placeholder for a Instance object that can be managed on the grid.

        See Also:
        Constant Field Values

      • optn_alpha

        protected double optn_alpha
        Colony similarity coefficient alpha. The larger, the more similar the colonies must be.

      • optn_kp

        protected double optn_kp
        Pick up threshold constant. Used for adjusting the pick up probability. Must be greater than 0.

      • optn_kd

        protected double optn_kd
        Drop down threshold constant. Used for adjusting the drop down probability.

      • optn_kdFunction

        protected int optn_kdFunction
        Which kd function should be used.

      • optn_distanceFunction

        protected weka.core.DistanceFunction optn_distanceFunction
        The distance function used for determining the distance between instances.

      • optn_gridSizeX

        protected int optn_gridSizeX
        Width of the grid.

      • optn_gridSizeY

        protected int optn_gridSizeY
        Height of the grid.

      • optn_antCycles

        protected int optn_antCycles
        Maximum number of ant cycles to be executed.

      • optn_antsCallPerAntCycle

        protected int optn_antsCallPerAntCycle
        How many ants should be called in one ant cycle.

        For each call an ant is selected randomly. An ant cycle is done when there are as many ants called as specified here. As the selection of an ant is random, an ant can also be called several times in the same ant cycle, whereas other ants may not be called during one ant cycle.

      • optn_antsNum

        protected int optn_antsNum
        Number of ants on the grid.

      • optn_antsViewRange

        protected int optn_antsViewRange
        Size of the view range of ant ant or neighborhood radius s on the grid.

        All instances within the radius are regarded as neighbors. The ant view range is measured in grid cells surrounding one ant. It has the shape of a square. When the ant view range is 0, the ant view range is limited to the grid cell the ant sits on. As this does not lead to clustering the ant view range must be at least 1.

      • optn_antsSpeedDistributionLimit

        protected int optn_antsSpeedDistributionLimit
        Maximum ant speed, how many steps an ant can make on the grid in one turn.

        A step means an ant is going from one grid cell to a neighbor grid cell, diagonal cells not included. When this value is greater than 1, ants can have different speeds. For example, if the speed distribution limit is 10, there are 10 groups of ants with the speeds 1,2,..,10. The clusterer tries to keep the groups of equal size, although this is not possible when the division of ant count / speed distribution limit has a rest. In this case the ant speed groups do not all have the same size.

      • optn_antsDropRange

        protected int optn_antsDropRange
        The ant drop range is the area in which ants can drop instances they carry.

        It is measured in grid cells surrounding an ant, so that the area has the shape of a square. When the ant drop range is 0, the ant can drop the instance it carries only at its position and if there is no instance yet. In other cases the ant drops the instance to a random and free grid cell in this as soon as the ant decided to drop its carried instance.

      • optn_antsDropMemorySize

        protected int optn_antsDropMemorySize
        Number of drop locations an ant can remember.

        The ant will remember its recent drop locations and when it picks up a new instance it checks its memory and retrieves the instance that is most similar to the instance picked up just now. Then the ant goes in the direction to where it dropped the memorized instance. As soon the ant reaches the memorized location it starts walking randomly again, no matter if it dropped the instance there or not. When the ant picks up another instance the process starts again. Ants do not have a drop location memory when this option is set to -1.

      • optn_antsBehaviorDestructiveAfterNumFreeCycles

        protected int optn_antsBehaviorDestructiveAfterNumFreeCycles
        After how many ant cycles carrying nothing the ant switches to destructive behavior.

        When an ant did not pick up an instance for the given amount of ant cycles it becomes destructive and picks up the next instance regardless of the neighborhood of the instance. Set to -1 to deactivate this behavior.

      • optn_antsBehaviorDestructiveForNextPickUps

        protected int optn_antsBehaviorDestructiveForNextPickUps
        How many times an ant will pick up an instance in destructive behavior before the ant switches back to normal pick up behavior.

        Destructive pick up behavior means the ant picks up instances regardless of the instance environments, therefore the ant does not care if it destroys clusters of already grouped instances. After an ant picked up enough instances in that behavior it turns back to normal pick up behavior again. This value determines how many instances the ant wants to pick up without caring for the instance environment, before it switches back to normal behavior. When this value is -1, the ant remains destructive.

      • optn_replaceMissing

        protected boolean optn_replaceMissing
        Replace missing values globally?

      • optn_gridClusterer

        protected weka.clusterers.Clusterer optn_gridClusterer
        Clusterer that is used to explain the clusters (instance groups) on the grid.

      • alpha

        protected double alpha
        The current alpha value.

      • data

        protected weka.core.Instances data
        Instances to be clustered.

        This variable holds the given Instances object, which contains all Instance objects to be clustered. This variable is best understood as a global variable and once the Instances are assigned, it must not be altered anymore. Other classes of this clusterer rely on the contents of this variable and expect that this variable is available.

        See Also:
        Instances

      • setDropDownFunction

        public void setDropDownFunction(weka.core.SelectedTag value)
                         throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Sets the drop down function. Two functions are accepted: The original function is the one used by Lumer/Faieta 1994 and described in getTechnicalInformation(). The other one is the symmetric counterpart to the pick up function and suggested by Deneubourg/Goss/ Franks/Sendova-Franks/Detrain/Chretien 1991.
        Parameters:
        value - a SelectedTag describing the drop down function to use.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if in debug mode and value is not a known SelectedTag.

      • getDropDownFunction

      • setAntsSpeedDistributionLimit

        public void setAntsSpeedDistributionLimit(int value)
                                   throws java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
        Sets the maximum speed of the ants.
        Parameters:
        value - the maximum speed an ant can have.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if value is smaller than one and debug mode is activated.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if there are not enough ants available to increment the speed from 1 to value with step size 1 and assign this speed to at least one ant. This is the case when value > getAntsNum().

      • indexOfInstanceInInstances

        protected static int indexOfInstanceInInstances(weka.core.Instances instances,
                                                weka.core.Instance instance)
        Tells the index of an Instance object in a Instances object.

        This is an alternative method for the instances.indexOf(instance) task, but does not use the instance.equals(Object obj) invoked by instances.indexOf(instance). For the context this method is used in, the instances.indexOf(instance) did not work as desired, so this method was written. If there is a way to execute also indexOf, this method becomes obsolete.

        Parameters:
        instances - Instances to search in
        instance - the Instance to search for in instances
        Returns:
        index of instance in instances or -1 if instance was not found.
